articles.headline: In a Trade War, China Might Boycott U.S. Goods. That Could Backfire.
articles.snippet: State media have hinted that Beijing could weaponize its consumers in a trade war. But American brands are popular in China — and Chinese workers make many of their products.
articles.abstract: State media have hinted that Beijing could weaponize its consumers in a trade war. But American brands are popular in China — and Chinese workers make many of their products.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAICANG, China — If China calls for a boycott of American goods, Chinese workers like David Xu could be in trouble.
articles.byline: By Sui-Lee Wee and Zhang Tiantian

articles.headline: Punishing Wells Fargo: Just Deserts, or Beating a Dead Horse?
articles.snippet: The bank deserved to pay for its reprehensible transgressions. But our columnist asks whether further punishment may just be hurting the shareholders.
articles.abstract: The bank deserved to pay for its reprehensible transgressions. But our columnist asks whether further punishment may just be hurting the shareholders.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo investors got yet another jolt of bad news on Thursday with the disclosure that regulators are poised to impose a $1 billion penalty on the bank for infractions related to mortgage rate extensions, auto loans, risk compliance and other matters.

articles.headline: McCabe Report Is Sent to Prosecutors to Weigh Possible Criminal Inquiry
articles.snippet: The Justice Department inspector general concluded in a scathing report that Andrew McCabe, the fired F.B.I. official, lacked candor when answering investigators’ questions.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department inspector general concluded in a scathing report that Andrew McCabe, the fired F.B.I. official, lacked candor when answering investigators’ questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal prosecutors are examining whether they have sufficient evidence to open a criminal investigation into Andrew G. McCabe, the former F.B.I. deputy director, his lawyer said on Thursday, after a Justice Department inspector general report repeatedly faulted him for misleading investigators.
articles.byline: By Adam Goldman, Katie Benner and Alexandra Alter

articles.headline: Wells Fargo Said to Be Target of $1 Billion U.S. Fine
articles.snippet: Two federal regulators are expected to penalize the bank for its alleged misconduct, people familiar with the action said.
articles.abstract: Two federal regulators are expected to penalize the bank for its alleged misconduct, people familiar with the action said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators are poised to impose a $1 billion fine on Wells Fargo for years of selling unnecessary products to customers, the toughest action by the Trump administration against a major bank.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter and Glenn Thrush

articles.headline: A.I. Researchers Are Making More Than $1 Million, Even at a Nonprofit
articles.snippet: Tax forms filed by OpenAI provide insight into the enormous salaries and bonuses paid to artificial intelligence specialists across the world.
articles.abstract: Tax forms filed by OpenAI provide insight into the enormous salaries and bonuses paid to artificial intelligence specialists across the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — One of the poorest-kept secrets in Silicon Valley has been the huge salaries and bonuses that experts in artificial intelligence can command. Now, a little-noticed tax filing by a research lab called OpenAI has made some of those eye-popping figures public.

articles.headline: CNN’s Jake Tapper Has Emerged as a Staunch Defender of Facts in the Trump Era. So Why Is He Writing Fiction?
articles.snippet: Tapper’s debut novel, “The Hellfire Club,” a historical thriller set in 1950s Washington, has some unsettling parallels to today’s political climate.
articles.abstract: Tapper’s debut novel, “The Hellfire Club,” a historical thriller set in 1950s Washington, has some unsettling parallels to today’s political climate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jake Tapper doesn’t seem to get rattled easily. He’s got a TV anchor’s unflappable poise and immovable hair, and radiates an almost eerie calm when a dozen explosive stories break during his daily CNN show. He’s weathered relentless online attacks from the right for his interrogations of Trump administration officials, and seemed unruffled when the president attacked him as a “CNN flunky” on Twitter. (Mr. Tapper retweeted the message, with an eye-roll emoji.)

articles.headline: Giuliani to Join Trump’s Legal Team
articles.snippet: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York City mayor and longtime Trump loyalist, will be part of a legal stable as the president faces the Russia investigation.
articles.abstract: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York City mayor and longtime Trump loyalist, will be part of a legal stable as the president faces the Russia investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York City mayor and longtime friend of President Trump, will join the president’s legal team in an effort to “quickly” resolve the special counsel investigation into Russian election interference and possible ties to Trump associates.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Sanctions Are Hurting North Korea. Can They Make Kim Give In?
articles.snippet: The isolated North is finding ways to cope with tough new penalties. Is the economic pressure enough to get Kim Jong-un to give up his weapons?
articles.abstract: The isolated North is finding ways to cope with tough new penalties. Is the economic pressure enough to get Kim Jong-un to give up his weapons?
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — On a dark February night, the trucks unloaded their contraband near Hyesan, a North Korean town across a narrow river from China. As border guards looked the other way, workers used carts to pull the cargo of metal ore — tungsten, lead, zinc, copper and gold concentrates, all banned from export under United Nations sanctions — across the frozen river.

articles.headline: ‘We No Longer Need’ Nuclear or Missile Tests, North Korean Leader Says
articles.snippet: The announcement by Kim Jong-un came less than a week before he meets with the president of South Korea.
articles.abstract: The announcement by Kim Jong-un came less than a week before he meets with the president of South Korea.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, announced early Saturday that his country no longer needed to test nuclear weapons or long-range missiles and would close a nuclear test site.

articles.headline: Trump Criticizes OPEC, Calling Oil Prices ‘Artificially’ High
articles.snippet: The president’s remarks came with gasoline prices at their highest point in three years after an effort by the oil cartel and Russia to restrain output.
articles.abstract: The president’s remarks came with gasoline prices at their highest point in three years after an effort by the oil cartel and Russia to restrain output.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — As domestic gasoline prices surged to their highest level in three years, President Trump railed against the OPEC oil cartel on Friday, declaring that the group was unjustifiably manipulating supplies for selfish gain.

articles.headline: Charges Sought in Eric Garner’s Death, but Justice Officials Have Doubts
articles.snippet: Prosecutors recommended charging a New York police officer, but others question whether the case can be won. Mr. Garner’s gasps of “I can’t breathe” galvanized protesters.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors recommended charging a New York police officer, but others question whether the case can be won. Mr. Garner’s gasps of “I can’t breathe” galvanized protesters.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal civil rights prosecutors have recommended charges against a New York police officer in the 2014 death of Eric Garner, three current and former officials said, but top Justice Department officials have expressed strong reservations about whether to move forward with a case they say may not be winnable.
